properties.description: Salt merchant-funded troupes (e.g., Chuntai Troupe) fused Anqing Mandarin with Suzhou Kunqu, giving rise to Ruantan, an early form of Peking Opera.
While Kunqu was originally sung in Wu dialect, by the Qing dynasty, to appeal to northern audiences, jing (painted-face) and chou (comic) roles began using Mandarin, as noted in Lüyuan Conghua.
While Kunqu was originally sung in Wu dialect, by the Qing dynasty, to appeal to northern audiences, jing (painted-face) and chou (comic) roles began using Mandarin, as noted in Lüyuan Conghua.

Boatmen and guards from the north brought retroflex sounds and words like “ǎn” to Xuzhou. Meanwhile, southern workers introduced Wu dialect terms, making Xuzhou a blend of northern and southern speech along the canal.
